funFacts: The first known recipe for a 'Some More' was published in the 1927 Girl Scout handbook 'Tramping and Trailing with the Girl Scouts.'
The name 's'more' is widely believed to be a contraction of 'some more,' reflecting the popular demand for an additional serving of the treat.
Americans purchase over 90 million pounds of marshmallows each year, with a significant portion being used for s'mores, especially during summer months.
08-10.name: S'mores Day

08-11.description: National Raspberry Bombe Day, observed annually on August 11th, celebrates a classic frozen dessert characterized by its spherical or dome shape, typically created in a mold. A raspberry bombe features the sweet-tart flavor of raspberries, often layered with ice cream, sorbet, or mousse, offering a refreshing and elegant treat perfect for summer.
funFacts: The term 'bombe glac√©e' (frozen bombe) originated in France in the 19th century.
A traditional bombe is made by lining a spherical mold with one type of ice cream or sorbet, filling the center with another flavor or mixture, and then freezing it solid.
Raspberries are not true berries botanically but are aggregate fruits composed of many tiny drupelets around a central core.
08-11.name: National Raspberry Bombe Day

08-11.description: Presidential Joke Day, observed annually on August 11th, is an unofficial American holiday celebrating the humor, wit, and often self-deprecating jokes shared by U.S. presidents throughout history. It commemorates the day in 1984 when President Ronald Reagan, while testing a microphone for a radio address, jokingly announced, "My fellow Americans, I'm pleased to tell you today that I've signed legislation that will outlaw Russia forever. We start bombing in five minutes." This lighthearted, unbroadcast moment sparked both amusement and minor controversy, reminding the public that even leaders in high office possess a human side capable of humor.
funFacts: The holiday originated from an unbroadcast microphone test by Ronald Reagan in 1984, where he joked about bombing Russia.
Abraham Lincoln was renowned for using humor and storytelling, often to explain complex issues or relieve stress during the Civil War.
Many presidents, including John F. Kennedy and Barack Obama, frequently used self-deprecating humor to connect with the public and defuse tension.
08-11.name: Presidential Joke Day

08-12.description: National Julienne Fries Day, celebrated annually on August 12th, honors the popular thin-cut potato snack. Julienne refers to a specific culinary cutting technique where food, in this case, potatoes, is sliced into long, thin strips, typically about 1/8 inch thick. These slender fries are known for their crispy texture and quick cooking time, making them a beloved variation of the classic fried potato.
funFacts: The 'julienne' cut is a classical French culinary term, referring to food items cut into long, thin matchstick-like strips.
True julienne cuts are typically 1/8 inch by 1/8 inch by 1-2 inches in length, though the precise dimensions can vary slightly.
While often used interchangeably, 'julienne fries' and 'shoestring fries' both refer to very thin potato fries, with some sources suggesting shoestring fries are even thinner.
08-12.name: National Julienne Fries Day

08-12.description: Middle Child's Day, observed annually on August 12, is an informal holiday dedicated to recognizing and celebrating individuals who are the middle child in their family's birth order. It highlights the unique position, perceived challenges, and often-praised qualities associated with being neither the eldest nor the youngest, such as adaptability, strong negotiation skills, and independence. The day serves as an opportunity to appreciate their often-overlooked contributions and distinct personality traits.
funFacts: While not a federal holiday, Middle Child's Day gained popularity through social media and is celebrated globally by families and individuals.
Birth order theory suggests middle children often develop strong diplomatic skills, becoming excellent mediators due to navigating relationships between older and younger siblings.
Several influential figures are believed to have been middle children, including Abraham Lincoln, Bill Gates, and Madonna, often cited as examples of their independence and drive.
08-12.name: Middle Child's Day

08-13.description: International Left-Handers Day, celebrated annually on August 13th, is dedicated to raising public awareness of the advantages and disadvantages of being left-handed in a predominantly right-handed world. It aims to highlight the unique challenges left-handed individuals face, such as using tools and navigating a world designed for right-handers, while also celebrating their distinct perspective and contributions.
funFacts: Approximately 10-12% of the world's population is left-handed.
Left-handers are often observed to have an advantage in certain sports, such as tennis and boxing, due to their unique angle of play.
Four of the last seven U.S. Presidents (Reagan, George H.W. Bush, Bill Clinton, and Barack Obama) were left-handed.
08-13.name: International Left-Handers Day

08-13.description: National Filet Mignon Day, celebrated annually on August 13th, is an unofficial holiday dedicated to appreciating one of the most prized cuts of beef. Filet mignon, French for 'dainty fillet,' is renowned for its exceptional tenderness, buttery texture, and mild flavor, derived from the small end of the beef tenderloin. The day encourages enthusiasts to indulge in this luxurious steak, whether prepared at home or enjoyed at a restaurant, celebrating its culinary appeal.
funFacts: The term 'filet mignon' is French for 'dainty fillet,' reflecting its delicate nature and smaller size.
Filet mignon comes from the very tender, non-weight-bearing psoas major muscle, located in the short loin of the cow.
Due to its low fat content, filet mignon is often wrapped in bacon or served with rich sauces to enhance its flavor profile.
08-13.name: National Filet Mignon Day

08-14.description: National Creamsicle Day is celebrated annually on August 14th, a day dedicated to honoring the beloved frozen treat. This nostalgic dessert features a creamy vanilla ice cream core surrounded by a refreshing, fruity, and typically orange-flavored sherbet coating. It's a perfect occasion to enjoy the classic sweet and tangy combination that has been a summer favorite for generations.
funFacts: The Creamsicle was invented by Frank Epperson, who also created the Popsicle, when he was just 11 years old.
While often used generically, 'Creamsicle' is a registered trademark of Unilever, specifically referring to their brand of the treat.
The original and most iconic flavor is orange, but Creamsicles have also been produced in other fruit flavors such as grape and cherry.
08-14.name: National Creamsicle Day

08-14.description: National Kool-Aid Day, celebrated annually on August 14th, honors the beloved powdered drink mix that has been a staple in American households for generations. It's a day to remember the joy and refreshment Kool-Aid brings, often associated with childhood memories, summer days, and vibrant, fruity flavors. People celebrate by mixing up a pitcher of their favorite flavor, sharing stories, and sometimes even experimenting with recipes that incorporate the iconic drink.
funFacts: Kool-Aid was invented in 1927 by Edwin Perkins in Hastings, Nebraska.
Before becoming a powdered mix, it was first sold as a liquid concentrate called "Fruit Smack."
The iconic Kool-Aid Man character, known for his "Oh Yeah!" catchphrase, first appeared in advertising in 1975.
08-14.name: National Kool-Aid Day

08-15.description: National Leathercraft Day, observed annually on August 15th, celebrates the ancient art and skill of working with leather. This day honors the artisans, hobbyists, and manufacturers who transform animal hides into beautiful and functional items, highlighting the creativity, precision, and historical significance of this enduring craft.
funFacts: Leatherworking is one of humanity's oldest crafts, with evidence dating back to prehistoric times when it was essential for clothing, shelter, and tools.
Common leathercraft techniques include tooling, carving, dyeing, stamping, lacing, and stitching, allowing for a wide range of decorative and functional finishes.
Products made through leathercraft range from everyday items like belts, wallets, and shoes to intricate artwork, saddles, and specialized equipment.
08-15.name: National Leathercraft Day

08-15.description: The holiday 'Chauvin Day' on August 15th is not a recognized or established celebration in any factual, historical, or cultural context. There is no verifiable evidence of such a day being observed.
funFacts: The term 'chauvinism,' denoting excessive or blind patriotism, is attributed to Nicolas Chauvin, a legendary soldier of Napoleon Bonaparte's army.
August 15th is widely recognized as Assumption Day by Roman Catholics and Orthodox Christians, commemorating the belief in the Virgin Mary's bodily assumption into Heaven.
Several nations observe national holidays on August 15th, including India's Independence Day, South Korea's Gwangbokjeol (National Liberation Day), and various countries celebrating Assumption Day.
08-15.name: Chauvin Day

08-16.description: National Tell a Joke Day, observed annually on August 16th, is an unofficial holiday dedicated to the sharing of humor and the simple joy of laughter. It encourages people to lighten the mood, engage in playful banter, and spread cheer by telling jokes, whether they be silly puns, classic knock-knocks, or clever one-liners, highlighting the universal appeal and positive impact of comedy.
funFacts: National Tell a Joke Day is celebrated every year on August 16th.
Laughter has been scientifically shown to reduce stress hormones, boost the immune system, and improve overall mood.
The oldest known joke, dating back to 1900 BC from Sumeria, involves flatulence, showcasing humor's ancient origins.
08-16.name: National Tell a Joke Day

08-16.description: National Rum Day, celebrated annually on August 16th, is an unofficial observance dedicated to the versatile distilled spirit derived from sugarcane. It's a day for rum enthusiasts and casual drinkers alike to appreciate rum in its many forms, whether enjoyed neat, on the rocks, or as a key ingredient in popular cocktails, highlighting its rich history and diverse flavor profiles.
funFacts: Rum production originated in the Caribbean in the 17th century.
The British Royal Navy historically issued a daily ration of rum to its sailors, known as a "tot."
Rum is distilled from sugarcane molasses or fresh sugarcane juice.
08-16.name: Rum Day

08-17.description: National Black Cat Appreciation Day, observed annually on August 17th, is dedicated to celebrating the unique beauty, charm, and loving nature of black cats. The day aims to dispel harmful superstitions and negative stereotypes often associated with these felines, encouraging people to recognize their often overlooked status in animal shelters and promoting their adoption as cherished companions.
funFacts: Historically, black cats were associated with bad luck in parts of medieval Europe, but were considered good luck and symbols of prosperity in ancient Egypt, Japan, and parts of the UK.
A black cat's fur color is due to a dominant gene, and they can have either amber, green, or gold eyes, which often stand out strikingly against their dark coats.
Black cats are statistically less likely to be adopted from shelters compared to cats of other colors, often spending more time waiting for a home.
08-17.name: National Black Cat Appreciation Day

08-17.description: Thrift Shop Day, observed annually on August 17th, encourages individuals to explore second-hand stores for unique finds, sustainable shopping, and budget-friendly purchases. It highlights the environmental benefits of reducing waste and extending the life of products, supports local charities and communities, and promotes a mindful approach to consumption by giving pre-owned items a new home.
funFacts: Buying a used garment can reduce its carbon footprint by 82% compared to purchasing new.
The global second-hand apparel market is projected to reach $350 billion by 2027.
Many shoppers find unique, vintage, or even valuable designer items at a fraction of their original cost in thrift stores.
08-17.name: Thrift Shop Day

08-18.description: National Bad Poetry Day, observed annually on August 18th, is a lighthearted occasion dedicated to the deliberate creation and appreciation of truly terrible verse. Far from celebrating literary masterpieces, this day encourages participants to shed the pressure of poetic perfection and instead embrace humor, silliness, and the joy of breaking all the rules of rhythm, rhyme, and reason. It's a chance for anyone to write poetry, no matter how nonsensical or poorly constructed, fostering creativity through imperfection.
funFacts: It is celebrated every year on August 18th.
The day encourages people to write poetry that is intentionally poor, often for comedic effect.
Many participate by writing limericks, haikus, or free verse, aiming for maximum cringe or laughter.
08-18.name: National Bad Poetry Day

08-18.description: Serendipity Day, observed on August 18th, is an informal holiday that celebrates the concept of serendipity ‚Äì the occurrence and development of events by chance in a happy or beneficial way. It encourages individuals to be open to unexpected fortunate discoveries, appreciate the joy of pleasant surprises, and recognize the role of chance in positive outcomes in daily life.
funFacts: The word "serendipity" was coined by English author Horace Walpole in 1754, inspired by the Persian fairy tale "The Three Princes of Serendip."
"Serendip" is an ancient Persian name for Sri Lanka, where the tale's princes often made fortunate discoveries.
Many significant scientific and technological advancements, such as the discovery of penicillin by Alexander Fleming and the invention of Post-it Notes, were the result of serendipitous events.
08-18.name: Serendipity Day

08-19.description: National Soft Ice Cream Day, observed annually on August 19th, is a delightful occasion dedicated to celebrating the distinctively creamy, smooth, and often swirled frozen dessert. This day encourages enthusiasts to indulge in the beloved treat, appreciating its unique texture and cooler serving temperature compared to traditional hard-scooped ice cream, making it a perfect summer indulgence.
funFacts: The origins of soft serve are widely attributed to several figures, including Tom Carvel (whose ice cream truck broke down in 1934) and Dairy Queen (which began serving soft serve in 1938).
Soft serve is typically served at a higher temperature (around 25¬∞F or -4¬∞C) than traditional hard-scooped ice cream, contributing to its smoother, less icy texture.
A significant amount of air, known as 'overrun,' is incorporated into soft serve during its creation, often making up 30-60% of its volume, which gives it its characteristic lightness.
08-19.name: National Soft Ice Cream Day

08-19.description: National Potato Day, observed annually on August 19th, is a celebration dedicated to one of the world's most versatile and widely consumed staple foods. This day encourages people to appreciate the potato's rich history, nutritional value, and countless culinary applications, recognizing its significant role in global agriculture and diverse cuisines.
funFacts: Potatoes were first cultivated by Inca Indians in Peru around 8,000 to 5,000 B.C.
There are over 4,000 varieties of potatoes cultivated worldwide, each with unique characteristics.
In 1995, potatoes became the first food grown in space when NASA and the University of Wisconsin, Madison, collaborated on research aboard the Space Shuttle Columbia.
08-19.name: National Potato Day

08-20.description: National Radio Day, observed annually on August 20th, celebrates the invention of radio and its profound impact on communication, entertainment, and information dissemination worldwide. It's a day to recognize the historical significance of this medium, its evolution from early telegraphy to modern digital broadcasting, and its enduring role in connecting communities, delivering news, and providing diverse programming across the globe.
funFacts: Guglielmo Marconi is widely credited with inventing radio telegraphy and sending the first transatlantic radio signal in 1901.
The first public radio broadcast of voice and music is attributed to Reginald Fessenden on Christmas Eve 1906, from Brant Rock, Massachusetts.
KDKA in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, generally recognized as the first commercial radio station, began broadcasting on November 2, 1920.
08-20.name: National Radio Day

08-20.description: National Chocolate Pecan Pie Day, observed annually on August 20th, celebrates a decadent dessert that combines the rich, buttery crunch of pecans with the sweet indulgence of chocolate, all nestled in a flaky pie crust. This delightful variation on the classic pecan pie offers a perfect balance of textures and flavors, making it a beloved treat particularly associated with American Southern cuisine. It's a day for enthusiasts to bake, share, and savor this rich confection.
funFacts: While the exact origin of traditional pecan pie is debated, its widespread popularity solidified in the American South, with the chocolate variation emerging as a beloved modern twist.
Pecans are the only major tree nut native to North America, and the United States is currently the world's leading producer.
The word 'pecan' is derived from the Algonquin word 'pakani,' which refers to a nut that requires a stone to crack.
08-20.name: National Chocolate Pecan Pie Day

08-21.description: National Spumoni Day, celebrated annually on August 21st, honors the classic Italian molded ice cream dessert. Spumoni typically features three distinct flavored layers‚Äîmost commonly pistachio, cherry (or strawberry), and chocolate‚Äîsometimes incorporating candied fruits and nuts, offering a rich and elegant frozen treat.
funFacts: Spumoni originated in Naples, Italy, during the 19th century.
The name "spumoni" comes from the Italian word "spuma," meaning "foam," referring to its light, aerated texture.
Traditional spumoni layers often include pistachio (green), cherry or strawberry (red), and chocolate (brown), sometimes representing the colors of the Italian flag.
08-21.name: National Spumoni Day

08-21.description: Spumoni Day, celebrated annually on August 21st, honors the classic Italian molded ice cream dessert known for its distinctive layered flavors and textures. Originating in Naples, Spumoni traditionally combines three specific ice cream flavors‚Äîoften pistachio, cherry or strawberry, and chocolate‚Äîsometimes interspersed with candied fruits, nuts, or whipped cream, creating a festive and visually appealing treat that has become a beloved fixture in Italian-American cuisine.
funFacts: The name "spumoni" is derived from "spuma," the Italian word for "foam," referencing its characteristic airy quality.
Traditional spumoni often includes a layer of whipped cream or candied fruit between the ice cream layers, contributing to its complex texture.
Spumoni gained popularity in the United States through Italian immigrants, particularly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
08-21.name: Spumoni Day

08-22.description: Be an Angel Day, observed annually on August 22nd, encourages individuals to embody angelic qualities by performing acts of kindness and helpfulness for others. It's a day dedicated to spreading goodwill, offering support, and making a positive difference in the world, whether through small gestures or significant charitable contributions, reminding everyone of the impact of compassion and generosity.
funFacts: This unofficial holiday encourages both grand gestures of charity and simple, everyday acts of helpfulness, such as offering a listening ear or helping a neighbor.
The day promotes the idea of 'paying it forward,' where one good deed inspires another, creating a ripple effect of positivity.
Its observance is largely grassroots, celebrated through social media and community initiatives that foster a more compassionate and supportive world.
08-22.name: Be an Angel Day

08-22.description: National Pecan Torte Day, observed annually on August 22nd, invites dessert lovers to celebrate and indulge in the exquisite pecan torte. This sophisticated baked good is typically characterized by a dense, rich texture, often made with ground pecans, eggs, and sugar, and may contain little to no flour, distinguishing it from traditional cakes. It's a perfect day to bake one from scratch, enjoy a slice with coffee, or explore various recipes highlighting the delicious native nut.
funFacts: A torte, derived from the German word for cake, typically refers to a rich, often multilayered cake made with ground nuts (like pecans) or breadcrumbs instead of or in addition to flour.
Pecans are the only major tree nut native to North America, primarily cultivated in the southern and central United States and parts of Mexico.
The pecan tree (Carya illinoinensis) is the state tree of Texas.
08-22.name: National Pecan Torte Day

08-23.description: Ride the Wind Day, observed annually on August 23rd, is an unofficial holiday that encourages individuals to acknowledge, appreciate, and interact with the natural force of wind. It's a day to embrace outdoor activities like flying kites, sailing, or simply feeling the breeze, celebrating the wind's power and its presence in our world.
funFacts: Kites, a popular way to 'ride the wind,' were invented in China over 2,000 years ago.
Wind is a vital source of renewable energy, generating electricity without burning fossil fuels.
The fastest recorded surface wind speed on Earth (not from a tornado) was 231 mph (372 km/h) on Mount Washington, New Hampshire, in 1934.
08-23.name: Ride the Wind Day

08-23.description: Sponge Cake Day, celebrated annually on August 23rd, honors the light, airy, and versatile sponge cake. Characterized by its delicate texture, achieved primarily through the air whipped into eggs rather than chemical leavening agents, this foundational cake serves as a beloved base for countless desserts, including layered cakes, Swiss rolls, trifles, and tiramisu, making it a cherished staple in culinary traditions worldwide.
funFacts: The earliest known sponge cake recipes date back to the Italian Renaissance, with some historians tracing its origins to even older Mediterranean desserts.
Traditional sponge cakes rely on the aeration of whipped eggs and sugar for their rise, giving them their characteristic light and bouncy texture without the need for baking powder or soda.
The 'Victoria Sponge,' a classic British tea-time cake featuring two sponge layers filled with jam and cream, was popularized during Queen Victoria's reign.
08-23.name: Sponge Cake Day

08-24.description: National Peach Pie Day, observed annually on August 24th, is an unofficial food holiday dedicated to celebrating the quintessential summer dessert. This day encourages enthusiasts to bake, share, and indulge in the sweet, fruity confection, often highlighting the peak season for fresh peaches. It's a perfect opportunity to enjoy a slice of this comforting pie, perhaps warm and topped with a scoop of vanilla ice cream.
funFacts: Peaches, the primary ingredient for the pie, originated in China over 2,000 years ago before spreading worldwide.
While Georgia is famously known as the "Peach State," California is actually the leading U.S. producer of peaches.
Peach pie is often considered a staple of Southern American cuisine, especially popular during the summer harvest season.
08-24.name: National Peach Pie Day

08-24.description: Vesuvius Day, observed annually on August 24th, commemorates the catastrophic eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 AD, which famously buried the Roman cities of Pompeii and Herculaneum under ash and pumice. This historical event provides an unparalleled snapshot of Roman daily life, preserving structures, artifacts, and even human forms, offering invaluable insights into the ancient world.
funFacts: Though traditionally set on August 24th, archaeological findings, such as autumnal fruits and heavier clothing worn by victims, suggest the eruption may have occurred later in the autumn, possibly October 79 AD.
The ash and pumice from the eruption preserved the cities and their inhabitants in such detail that archaeologists could create plaster casts of victims' final moments.
Mount Vesuvius is still an active stratovolcano and is considered one of the most dangerous volcanoes in the world due to the large, dense population living nearby.
08-24.name: Vesuvius Day

08-25.description: National Banana Split Day, celebrated annually on August 25th, honors the iconic ice cream dessert known for its delightful combination of flavors and textures. This beloved treat typically features a banana sliced lengthwise, three scoops of ice cream (traditionally vanilla, chocolate, and strawberry), various sauces, whipped cream, chopped nuts, and a cherry on top, offering a refreshing and indulgent experience.
funFacts: The banana split was invented in 1904 by 23-year-old David 'Doc' Strickler, an apprentice pharmacist, in Latrobe, Pennsylvania.
Strickler originally charged ten cents for his creation, which was double the price of other sundaes at the time.
Latrobe, Pennsylvania, hosts an annual Great American Banana Split Festival to commemorate its invention.
08-25.name: National Banana Split Day

08-25.description: Kiss and Make Up Day, observed annually on August 25th, is an unofficial holiday dedicated to resolving conflicts and mending strained relationships. It encourages individuals to put aside differences, offer apologies, extend forgiveness, and reconcile with friends, family members, or partners, fostering peace and renewed connection.
funFacts: While its exact origin is largely obscure, the day is widely celebrated as a gentle reminder to not let grudges fester.
The act of 'kissing and making up' often involves not just physical affection, but also a verbal agreement to forgive and move past a disagreement.
Studies in psychology consistently show that forgiveness and reconciliation can lead to reduced stress, improved mental well-being, and stronger social bonds.
08-25.name: Kiss and Make Up Day

08-26.description: National Dog Day, observed annually on August 26th, is a day dedicated to celebrating all dogs, regardless of breed, size, or age. Founded in 2004 by pet and family lifestyle expert Colleen Paige, the day aims to raise awareness about the number of dogs that need to be rescued each year, encourage adoption from shelters, and acknowledge the profound impact dogs have on human lives, from companionship to working roles.
funFacts: National Dog Day was founded in 2004 by Colleen Paige, a pet and family lifestyle expert and animal rescue advocate.
Paige also established other animal-focused holidays, including National Puppy Day, National Cat Day, and National Wildlife Day.
The day encourages dog owners to donate to animal shelters, volunteer, or adopt a dog in need, highlighting the importance of pet adoption.
08-26.name: National Dog Day

08-26.description: National Cherry Popsicle Day, observed annually on August 26th, celebrates the beloved frozen treat in its vibrant red, fruity, and refreshing cherry flavor. This unofficial holiday encourages people to cool down and enjoy the simple pleasure of a cherry-flavored popsicle, perfect for a late summer indulgence.
funFacts: The first frozen treat on a stick was accidentally invented in 1905 by 11-year-old Frank Epperson.
Epperson originally called his invention an 'Epsicle,' later changing it to 'Popsicle' at his children's suggestion.
Cherry consistently ranks as one of the most popular and top-selling popsicle flavors worldwide.
08-26.name: National Cherry Popsicle Day

08-27.description: There is no recognized holiday known as 'The Duchess Who Wasn't Day' on August 27th or any other date in historical records, cultural traditions, or official calendars. This 'holiday' appears to be fictional or non-existent, and no factual information about its observance can be provided.
funFacts: No historical records or cultural traditions support the existence of 'The Duchess Who Wasn't Day'.
This 'holiday' is not listed by major holiday calendars or recognized by any national or international bodies.
The name 'The Duchess Who Wasn't' suggests a fictional or metaphorical concept rather than a historical or celebrated event.
08-27.name: The Duchess Who Wasn't Day

08-27.description: Just Because Day, celebrated annually on August 27th, is an unofficial holiday that encourages individuals to act spontaneously and perform deeds simply for the sake of it, without requiring a specific reason or occasion. It promotes the idea of engaging in random acts of kindness, treating oneself to something special, or doing something out of the ordinary, all with the aim of spreading joy, fostering goodwill, or simply enjoying the moment for no reason other than 'just because.'
funFacts: The exact origins of Just Because Day are largely unrecorded, suggesting it evolved organically as a concept rather than being formally instituted.
It encourages breaking from routine and embracing spontaneity, promoting both self-care and generosity without expectation of return.
Popular activities include sending an unexpected card, giving a surprise gift, or performing a random act of kindness for a stranger.
08-27.name: Just Because Day

08-28.description: National Bow Tie Day, observed annually on August 28th, is a sartorial celebration dedicated to the distinctive and stylish neckwear. The day encourages individuals to don a bow tie, appreciating its history, versatility, and unique flair, whether for formal occasions, professional settings, or as a statement of personal style.
funFacts: The bow tie originated from the cravats worn by Croatian mercenaries during the 17th-century Thirty Years' War.
It is a mandatory component of the 'black tie' dress code, signifying formal evening wear.
Bow ties come in various shapes, including the classic 'butterfly,' the narrower 'batwing,' and the 'pointed' (or diamond point).
08-28.name: National Bow Tie Day

08-28.description: Race Your Mouse Around the Icons Day is a lighthearted, unofficial holiday observed annually on August 28th, encouraging computer users to take a whimsical break from their daily tasks. The day invites individuals to engage in a playful, self-imposed challenge of quickly navigating their computer mouse pointer around the various icons displayed on their desktop screen. It serves as a brief, entertaining diversion and a modern, tech-centric novelty that highlights the ubiquitous role of the computer mouse in everyday digital interaction.
funFacts: It is an unofficial, modern 'holiday' with no known formal origin or declaration, likely emerging from internet culture.
The 'race' is purely individual and metaphorical, involving no actual competition or organizations, simply a personal test of mouse dexterity.
The holiday encourages a brief, playful interruption to productivity, reminding users of the simple joy in interacting with their digital tools.
08-28.name: Race Your Mouse Around the Icons Day

08-29.description: National Chop Suey Day, observed annually on August 29th, celebrates the iconic dish deeply intertwined with American Chinese cuisine. Often consisting of meat (such as chicken, pork, or beef), eggs, and a variety of vegetables like bean sprouts, cabbage, and celery, stir-fried in a savory sauce and typically served over rice or noodles, chop suey is a testament to culinary adaptation and innovation, encouraging people to enjoy or learn about its unique history.
funFacts: Despite its common association with China, chop suey is widely believed to have originated in the United States as a creation of Chinese American cooks.
The name 'chop suey' (ÈõúÁ¢é, z√° su√¨) translates from Cantonese as 'miscellaneous pieces' or 'mixed bits,' referring to the diverse ingredients in the dish.
Chop suey played a significant role in popularizing Chinese food among the broader American public in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
08-29.name: National Chop Suey Day

08-29.description: According to Hoyle Day, observed annually on August 29th, celebrates the legacy of Edmond Hoyle, an 18th-century English writer renowned for his definitive works on the rules of card games. The phrase "according to Hoyle" has become a widely used idiom, meaning "strictly in accordance with the rules" or "correctly and properly." The day serves as a reminder to uphold fairness, precision, and adherence to established rules, whether in games, work, or daily life, honoring Hoyle's lasting contribution to codified standards.
funFacts: Edmond Hoyle (c. 1672‚Äì1769) was an English expert on games who published authoritative guides to popular card games like whist and backgammon.
His most famous work, "A Short Treatise on the Game of Whist," published in 1742, became the definitive authority on the game for over a century.
The idiom "according to Hoyle" originated from the widespread trust and respect for his rulebooks, implying that something is done strictly by the book or correctly.
08-29.name: According to Hoyle Day

08-30.description: National Beach Day, observed annually on August 30th, is an unofficial holiday dedicated to celebrating the beauty, ecological importance, and recreational opportunities offered by beaches. It encourages people to visit, appreciate, and help protect these vital coastal ecosystems, whether by relaxing by the shore, enjoying water activities, or participating in conservation efforts to keep them pristine.
funFacts: Most beach sand globally is primarily made of quartz, but can also include minerals, shell fragments, and volcanic rock.
The world's longest beach is Praia do Cassino in Brazil, stretching over 250 kilometers (150 miles).
An estimated 80% of all plastic pollution entering the ocean originates from land-based sources, often accumulating on beaches.
08-30.name: National Beach Day

08-30.description: Toasted Marshmallow Day, observed annually on August 30th, is an unofficial but widely celebrated holiday dedicated to the simple pleasure of roasting marshmallows. It encourages enthusiasts to gather around a campfire, fireplace, or even use a kitchen torch to achieve that perfectly golden-brown exterior and gooey, warm center, often enjoyed on their own or as part of s'mores.
funFacts: Marshmallows were originally made from the sap of the Mallow plant (Althaea officinalis) and used for medicinal purposes.
The modern marshmallow, made with gelatin instead of mallow sap, was invented in the late 19th century.
The S'more, a popular treat featuring toasted marshmallow, chocolate, and graham crackers, is believed to have originated with the Girl Scouts in the 1920s.
08-30.name: Toasted Marshmallow Day

08-31.description: National Matchmaker Day, observed annually on August 31st, is a day dedicated to appreciating the efforts of those who help others find love and companionship. This includes professional matchmakers, dating coaches, and even friends and family members who play Cupid. It's a time to acknowledge the crucial role these individuals play in fostering meaningful connections and building relationships, celebrating the art and intention behind bringing compatible people together.
funFacts: Matchmaking is an ancient profession, with records dating back to biblical times and various cultures across the globe employing matchmakers to arrange marriages or partnerships.
One of the most famous fictional matchmakers is Yente from the musical "Fiddler on the Roof," who tirelessly works to find suitable spouses for the young people of Anatevka.

While traditional matchmakers still exist, the digital age has transformed the industry, with online dating apps and services now acting as modern "matchmakers" by using algorithms to connect potential partners.
08-31.name: National Matchmaker Day

08-31.description: Eat Outside Day, observed annually on August 31st, encourages individuals to enjoy their meals al fresco. This day is dedicated to embracing the simple pleasure of dining outdoors, whether it's through a casual picnic in a park, a backyard barbecue, or a meal on a restaurant patio, often serving as a moment to appreciate the final warm days of summer.
funFacts: The term "picnic" originates from the French word "pique-nique," first appearing in the 17th century to describe people bringing their own wine to a meal.
Dining outdoors became a highly popular social activity during the Victorian era and was a recurring theme in Impressionist paintings, most famously √âdouard Manet's "Le D√©jeuner sur l'herbe."
Eating outdoors can offer benefits such as increased exposure to natural light and fresh air, which can contribute to improved mood and a sense of well-being.
08-31.name: Eat Outside Day

09-01.description: National Emma M. Nutt Day, observed annually on September 1st, commemorates Emma M. Nutt, who made history as the first female telephone operator in the United States. Hired by the Edwin Holmes Telephone Dispatch Company in Boston on this date in 1878, her employment marked a significant shift in the telecommunications industry, paving the way for countless women to join the workforce as operators, a role they soon dominated due to their perceived politeness and patience compared to their male predecessors.
funFacts: Emma M. Nutt was hired on September 1, 1878, by the Edwin Holmes Telephone Dispatch Company in Boston.
Before women like Nutt were hired, teenage boys typically served as telephone operators but were often criticized for rudeness.
Nutt reportedly worked as a telephone operator for an impressive 33 years, remaining in the role until at least 1911.
09-01.name: National Emma M. Nutt Day

09-01.description: No Rhyme or Reason Day, observed annually on September 1st, is an unofficial holiday that celebrates the illogical, the whimsical, and the purely spontaneous. It encourages individuals to embrace the nonsensical, do things without needing a clear purpose or justification, and step away from the demands of rationality. This day provides an opportunity to enjoy moments of absurdity and remind us that not everything in life requires a logical explanation or a predefined reason.
funFacts: The exact origin or creator of No Rhyme or Reason Day remains largely unknown, fitting the holiday's theme of unexplained occurrences.
Typical celebrations include wearing mismatched socks, eating dessert before dinner, or performing random acts of kindness just because.
It serves as a lighthearted reminder that embracing spontaneity and the absurd can be a refreshing break from everyday routines and expectations.
09-01.name: No Rhyme or Reason Day

09-02.description: National Pierce Your Ears Day, observed annually on September 2nd, is a lighthearted occasion dedicated to the enduring practice and fashion statement of ear piercing. It encourages individuals to celebrate their existing piercings, consider getting new ones, or simply appreciate the diverse cultural and personal significance of ear jewelry. The day highlights ear piercing's long history as a form of adornment and self-expression across various societies worldwide.
funFacts: The oldest evidence of ear piercing comes from √ñtzi the Iceman, a mummy dating back over 5,300 years, who had a stretched earlobe piercing of 7-11 mm in diameter.
Historically, ear piercings in various cultures were sometimes believed to ward off evil spirits, improve eyesight, or signify social status.
Ear piercing is one of the most widely accepted and common forms of body modification practiced across the globe today.
09-02.name: National Pierce Your Ears Day

09-02.description: National Blueberry Popsicle Day, observed annually on September 2nd, is an unofficial but delightful holiday dedicated to celebrating the refreshing and flavorful combination of blueberries and popsicles. It encourages individuals to cool down with a sweet, icy treat that incorporates the nutritional benefits of blueberries, often marking a final taste of summer's simple pleasures before the season fully transitions.
funFacts: The popsicle was accidentally invented in 1905 by 11-year-old Frank Epperson, who left a mixture of powdered soda and water with a stirring stick in it out overnight.
Blueberries are known for being rich in antioxidants, often earning them 'superfood' status.
North America is the world's leading producer of blueberries, which are native to the continent.
09-02.name: National Blueberry Popsicle Day

09-03.description: Skyscraper Day is observed annually on September 3rd, reportedly chosen to honor the birthdate of architect Louis Sullivan, often called the "father of the skyscraper." This day celebrates the engineering marvels and architectural ingenuity behind the world's tallest buildings, acknowledging their profound impact on urban landscapes, technological advancements, and human ambition to reach new heights.
funFacts: The term "skyscraper" originally emerged in the late 19th century, referring to buildings of 10-20 stories that were considered exceptionally tall for their time.
The development of steel-frame construction and the invention of the safety elevator by Elisha Otis in 1852 were crucial innovations that made true skyscrapers possible.
The world's current tallest skyscraper is the Burj Khalifa in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, standing at 828 meters (2,717 feet) with over 160 stories.
09-03.name: Skyscraper Day

09-03.description: National Welsh Rarebit Day, observed annually on September 3rd, celebrates a classic British dish renowned for its rich, savory flavor. Often mistaken for containing meat due to its archaic name "Welsh Rabbit," this comforting meal actually features a thick, melted cheese sauce‚Äîtypically made with Cheddar, ale or beer, mustard, and Worcestershire sauce‚Äîgenerously poured over toasted bread. It's a culinary tradition that highlights the simple yet delicious combination of quality cheese and toast, embodying a warm, satisfying comfort food.
funFacts: Despite its alternative name "Welsh Rabbit," the dish contains no actual rabbit; the "rabbit" part of the name is thought to be an old English jocular term, possibly implying it was a poor man's substitute for meat.
Early recipes for Welsh Rarebit date back to the 18th century, appearing in British cookbooks and referenced by figures like Samuel Johnson.
Variations of the dish include "Buck Rarebit," which adds a poached or fried egg on top, and "Blushing Rarebit," which incorporates tomatoes.
09-03.name: National Welsh Rarebit Day

09-04.description: National Macadamia Nut Day, observed annually on September 4th, celebrates the luxurious, buttery flavor and diverse culinary applications of the macadamia nut. This day encourages appreciation for these premium nuts, whether enjoyed as a snack, baked into desserts, or used in savory dishes. It highlights the unique qualities and tropical origins of this highly sought-after kernel.
funFacts: Macadamia nuts are native to the rainforests of eastern Australia.
They are known for having one of the hardest shells to crack among all nuts, requiring immense pressure.
Despite being a healthy snack for humans, macadamia nuts are toxic to dogs, potentially causing weakness and tremors.
09-04.name: National Macadamia Nut Day

09-04.description: Eat an Extra Dessert Day is an informal, annual observance celebrated on September 4th. This lighthearted holiday encourages individuals to treat themselves to an additional sweet treat beyond their usual daily allowance, promoting a moment of pure, guilt-free indulgence in various desserts such as cakes, cookies, ice cream, or pastries. It serves as a fun reminder to enjoy life's sweeter moments and provides an excuse for a little extra culinary delight.
funFacts: It is celebrated annually on September 4th, consistently marking the day for extra indulgence.
Like many 'food holidays,' its exact origin is largely unknown, often arising from popular culture or promotional initiatives rather than official declaration.
The holiday encourages the consumption of *any* type of dessert, from simple cookies to elaborate multi-layered cakes, emphasizing the 'extra' aspect rather than a specific treat.
09-04.name: Eat an Extra Dessert Day

09-05.description: National Cheese Pizza Day is an annual celebration observed on September 5th, dedicated to one of the world's most universally loved and iconic foods: the cheese pizza. This day honors the simple yet satisfying combination of crust, tomato sauce, and melted cheese, a foundational dish that serves as a canvas for countless variations but is perfectly delicious in its purest form. It's a day for pizza enthusiasts to enjoy the classic for its comforting flavor and widespread appeal.
funFacts: Mozzarella is the most commonly used cheese on pizza, prized for its excellent melt, stretch, and mild flavor.
The modern pizza, with its familiar combination of dough, tomato, and cheese, is widely believed to have originated in Naples, Italy.
Americans consume approximately 3 billion pizzas annually, with cheese pizza being a foundational and highly popular choice among them.
09-05.name: National Cheese Pizza Day

09-05.description: Be Late for Something Day, observed annually on September 5th, is an unofficial, lighthearted holiday that playfully encourages individuals to intentionally embrace tardiness for at least one event or appointment. Rather than promoting chronic lateness, it serves as a humorous reminder to sometimes slow down, reduce stress associated with strict schedules, and perhaps even challenge the societal pressure for constant punctuality. It's a day to lighten up and not always rush.
funFacts: It is an unofficial holiday, not recognized by any governmental or major institutional body.
The exact origins of 'Be Late for Something Day' are largely unknown, typical of many quirky, modern holidays.
The holiday offers a playful contrast to 'National Punctuality Day,' which is celebrated on January 12th.
09-05.name: Be Late for Something Day

09-06.description: National Coffee Ice Cream Day, observed annually on September 6th, is a delicious holiday dedicated to celebrating the rich and creamy frozen dessert that blends the bold flavor of coffee with the sweet indulgence of ice cream. It's a perfect occasion for enthusiasts to enjoy this unique treat, whether in a cone, a cup, or as part of a more elaborate dessert.
funFacts: Coffee-flavored ice cream is thought to have originated in Europe by the mid-18th century, with recipes appearing in French cookbooks.
It consistently ranks among the top 10 to 15 most popular ice cream flavors globally, cherished for its distinct bittersweet profile.
Many variations exist, often incorporating chocolate fudge swirls, chocolate-covered espresso beans, or coffee liqueur for added depth and texture.
09-06.name: National Coffee Ice Cream Day

09-06.description: Fight Procrastination Day, observed annually on September 6th, is an unofficial holiday dedicated to encouraging individuals to overcome the tendency to delay important tasks. It serves as a timely reminder to tackle responsibilities, projects, or goals that have been put off, promoting productivity and the satisfaction of completion. The day encourages proactive behavior, urging people to stop postponing and start acting on their to-do lists, ultimately aiming to reduce stress and increase efficiency by addressing pending items.
funFacts: It is an unofficial observance, created to motivate people to take immediate action on tasks they've been postponing.
Studies indicate that chronic procrastination affects approximately 15-20% of adults globally, and over 70% of college students.

Psychologists often describe procrastination as an emotional regulation problem, where individuals delay tasks to avoid negative feelings associated with them, rather than a mere time management issue.
09-06.name: Fight Procrastination Day

09-07.description: National Salami Day, observed annually on September 7th, is an unofficial holiday celebrating the rich history and diverse culinary applications of salami. This popular cured sausage, traditionally made from fermented and air-dried meat (often pork or beef), originated from ancient Roman and Greek traditions as a method of preserving meat. Today, salami is cherished worldwide for its distinct flavor and versatility, featuring prominently on charcuterie boards, in sandwiches, and as a popular pizza topping.
funFacts: The word "salami" comes from the Italian "salare," meaning "to salt," referring to the curing process essential for its preservation.
Historically, salami was a vital food source for peasants, providing a long-lasting, protein-rich staple that could be stored without refrigeration.
There are hundreds of varieties of salami produced globally, each with unique spices, aging processes, and regional characteristics, such as Genoa, Cotto, and Felino.
09-07.name: National Salami Day

09-07.description: National New Hampshire Day, observed annually on September 7th, is a celebration of the 'Granite State,' known for its rugged beauty, independent spirit, and pivotal role in American history. It's a day to appreciate New Hampshire's scenic White Mountains, its charming small towns, and its enduring motto, 'Live Free or Die,' which embodies its commitment to liberty and self-reliance.
funFacts: New Hampshire was the first of the thirteen colonies to declare its independence from Great Britain, doing so on January 5, 1776.
Mount Washington, located in the White Mountains, holds the record for the highest wind speed ever recorded on land not associated with a tornado, at 231 mph.
New Hampshire is one of only a few U.S. states that does not impose a general sales tax or a personal income tax on wages.
09-07.name: National New Hampshire Day

09-08.description: National Ampersand Day, observed annually on September 8th, is a celebration of the unique typographical symbol '&'. This day encourages appreciation for the character that elegantly represents the word 'and', recognizing its long history and continued presence in language, typography, and design.
funFacts: The ampersand is a ligature, meaning a combination of two or more letters into a single character, specifically derived from the Latin word 'et' for 'and'.
The word 'ampersand' itself originated from the phrase 'and per se and,' which was traditionally recited when the symbol was taught as the 27th character of the English alphabet.
For centuries, until around the mid-19th century, the ampersand was officially considered the 27th letter of the English alphabet.
09-08.name: National Ampersand Day

09-08.description: Pardon Day, observed annually on September 8th, is an unofficial observance that encourages individuals to consider the act of forgiving, whether it's forgiving oneself, others, or seeking forgiveness. While not a formal public holiday, it serves as a symbolic day to reflect on mercy, second chances, and the restorative power of pardons, both personal and official, highlighting the theme of absolution and moving forward.
funFacts: In the United States, presidential pardons are granted for federal offenses and restore certain rights, but do not expunge the conviction itself.
The U.S. Constitution (Article II, Section 2, Clause 1) grants the President the power to issue pardons and reprieves for federal crimes.
One of the most famous presidential pardons was granted by Gerald Ford to Richard Nixon in 1974 for any crimes he may have committed as president.
09-08.name: Pardon Day

09-09.description: National Teddy Bear Day, observed annually on September 9th, is a heartwarming occasion dedicated to celebrating the beloved stuffed animal that has brought comfort and companionship to generations worldwide. It's a day to appreciate the history of the teddy bear, its enduring appeal, and the special place it holds in the hearts of children and adults alike, often marked by playing with bears, sharing stories, or even acquiring new ones.
funFacts: The teddy bear was named after U.S. President Theodore "Teddy" Roosevelt after a political cartoon depicted him refusing to shoot a bear cub during a 1902 hunting trip.
The concept of the teddy bear emerged almost simultaneously in the United States by Morris Michtom and in Germany by the Steiff company, designed by Richard Steiff.
Early teddy bears were often made from mohair plush, filled with excelsior (wood wool), and featured fully jointed limbs.
09-09.name: National Teddy Bear Day

09-09.description: Wonderful Weirdos Day, observed annually on September 9th, is a lighthearted occasion dedicated to celebrating individuality, embracing one's unique quirks, and appreciating the diverse eccentricities in others. It encourages people to shed inhibitions, express their authentic selves, and recognize that what might be considered "weird" is often a source of strength, creativity, and joy. The day promotes self-acceptance and a broader appreciation for the delightful spectrum of human personalities.
funFacts: It is an unofficial, modern holiday celebrated annually, emphasizing the joy of individuality and embracing one's unique quirks.
Observed every September 9th, it encourages people to be their authentic selves and appreciate the eccentricities in others.
While its specific origin isn't widely documented, it has gained recognition across various "national day" calendars and social media as a day of self-acceptance.
09-09.name: Wonderful Weirdos Day

09-10.description: National TV Dinner Day, observed annually on September 10th, celebrates the iconic pre-portioned, frozen meal that revolutionized American dining. Introduced by Swanson in 1953, these convenient meals, often consumed in front of the television, quickly became a staple in households, symbolizing the post-war era's demand for efficiency and the growing popularity of home entertainment. The day recognizes the lasting cultural impact and nostalgic appeal of this frozen food innovation.
funFacts: The first Swanson TV Dinner, launched in 1953, featured a turkey dinner with cornbread dressing, peas, and sweet potatoes.
The original TV Dinner trays were made of aluminum, designed to be heated directly in the oven.
Swanson reportedly sold over 10 million TV Dinners in its first year of production.
09-10.name: National TV Dinner Day

09-10.description: TV Dinner Day, observed annually on September 10th, celebrates the iconic pre-packaged, frozen meal that revolutionized mealtime convenience. Introduced in the mid-20th century, TV dinners typically consist of a main course and side dishes compartmentalized in an aluminum or plastic tray, designed for easy heating and consumption, often while watching television. This day acknowledges the enduring legacy of a comfort food that offered a quick and effortless dining solution for countless households.
funFacts: The first official 'TV Dinner' was introduced by C.A. Swanson & Sons in 1953.
The concept for TV dinners reportedly arose from a need to utilize a surplus of 260 tons of frozen Thanksgiving turkeys.
Original TV dinners were served in aluminum trays designed to be heated in a conventional oven, often featuring a main course, a vegetable, and a potato.
09-10.name: TV Dinner Day

09-11.description: National Make Your Bed Day, observed annually on September 11th, encourages individuals to embrace the simple yet impactful habit of making their bed each morning. This day highlights the various benefits associated with this routine, from creating a tidy living space and fostering a sense of accomplishment to setting a productive and positive tone for the entire day. It serves as a reminder that small, disciplined actions can contribute significantly to overall well-being and daily structure.
funFacts: Admiral William H. McRaven's widely-shared 2014 commencement speech at the University of Texas at Austin famously advised, "If you want to change the world, start by making your bed," emphasizing the importance of accomplishing the first task of the day.
Psychologists and productivity experts often suggest that making your bed can serve as a "keystone habit," a small change that triggers a chain of other positive habits throughout the day.
Surveys have indicated that individuals who consistently make their beds often report feeling more organized, having better sleep quality, and a stronger sense of control over their lives.
09-11.name: National Make Your Bed Day

09-11.description: No News is Good News Day, observed annually on September 11th, is an unofficial holiday that encourages individuals to intentionally disconnect from the constant flow of information, including traditional news, social media, and digital updates. The day promotes the idea of taking a mental break from news consumption and information overload, fostering a sense of peace and calm by embracing the absence of new or potentially distressing information. It serves as a reminder to appreciate quietude and focus on one's immediate surroundings rather than external events.
funFacts: This unofficial holiday encourages a 'digital detox' from news and social media to reduce stress and anxiety.
The observance date of September 11th is often considered a deliberate counterpoint to a day historically associated with significant, often distressing, global news events.
The idiom 'no news is good news' itself suggests that the absence of information implies nothing bad has occurred, thus inferring a positive situation.
09-11.name: No News is Good News Day

09-12.description: National Chocolate Milkshake Day, observed annually on September 12th, is an unofficial but widely celebrated holiday dedicated to indulging in one of America's most iconic and beloved sweet treats. This day encourages individuals to enjoy the classic blend of chocolate, milk, and often ice cream, served cold and thick, recognizing its enduring popularity as a refreshing beverage or dessert.
funFacts: The term "milkshake" first appeared in print in 1885, originally referring to an alcoholic whiskey drink.
Ice cream wasn't a standard ingredient in milkshakes until the early 20th century, becoming widely popular around the 1920s.
The invention of the electric blender in 1922 significantly contributed to the widespread popularity of thick, frothy milkshakes, making them easier to prepare.
09-12.name: National Chocolate Milkshake Day

09-12.description: Chocolate Milkshake Day, observed annually on September 12th, is an unofficial but widely celebrated holiday dedicated to indulging in the rich, creamy, and beloved beverage. It encourages people to enjoy a classic chocolate milkshake, whether homemade, from a diner, or a fast-food establishment, honoring its enduring appeal as a sweet treat that evokes nostalgia and simple pleasure.
funFacts: The term "milkshake" first appeared in print in 1885, originally referring to an alcoholic drink with whiskey, eggs, and cream.

The modern, ice-cream-based milkshake became widely popular after the invention of electric blenders in the early 20th century, particularly with Stephen Poplawski's patent for the beverage mixer in 1922.
Chocolate remains one of the most consistently popular milkshake flavors globally, often rivaling vanilla in sales.
09-12.name: Chocolate Milkshake Day

09-13.description: Supernatural Day, observed annually on September 13th, is an unofficial fan holiday dedicated to celebrating the long-running American dark fantasy television series *Supernatural*. This date marks the premiere of the show's pilot episode in 2005, and fans worldwide use the day to honor the series' legacy, its beloved characters Sam and Dean Winchester, iconic storylines, and enduring themes of family, sacrifice, and the battle against supernatural evil.
funFacts: The holiday is celebrated on September 13th because that was the original air date of the *Supernatural* pilot episode in 2005.
*Supernatural* ran for an impressive 15 seasons, totaling 327 episodes, making it one of the longest-running fantasy/sci-fi series in U.S. television history.
The iconic 1967 Chevrolet Impala, affectionately known as 'Baby,' was nearly a 1965 Mustang or a 1969 Camaro before series creator Eric Kripke insisted on the Impala.
09-13.name: Supernatural Day

09-13.description: Fortune Cookie Day, observed annually on September 13th, celebrates the iconic crisp cookie known for its unique folded shape and the small paper slip tucked inside. These slips typically contain a proverb, a vague prophecy, or a set of lucky numbers, adding an element of surprise and whimsy to many dining experiences, particularly in Chinese-American restaurants.
funFacts: Despite their strong association with Chinese cuisine, fortune cookies originated in Japan, where they were known as 'tsujiura senbei' and appeared as early as the 19th century.
They became widely popular in the United States, particularly after World War II, when returning soldiers popularized them after encountering them in Japanese and Chinese-American restaurants.
Many fortune cookies include 'lucky numbers' which, despite being randomly generated, have occasionally been used by people who later won lotteries.
09-13.name: Fortune Cookie Day

09-14.description: National Cream-Filled Donut Day, observed annually on September 14th, is a delightful occasion dedicated to celebrating the rich, sweet, and often decadent pastry filled with various creamy concoctions. Whether it's classic Bavarian cream, luscious Boston cream, or light whipped cream, this day encourages donut lovers to indulge in the unique experience of biting into a soft, fluffy donut bursting with delicious filling. It's a sweet tribute to one of the most beloved variations of the popular fried treat.
funFacts: The Boston cream donut, a popular cream-filled variety, is inspired by the Boston cream pie, which features a custard filling and chocolate glaze.
Cream-filled donuts are often filled after frying and cooling using a pastry bag or specialized injector to ensure the cream remains fresh and doesn't cook during frying.
Many cultures have their own versions of filled donuts, such as the German Berliner Pfannkuchen, which is typically filled with jam or marmalade but can also have cream fillings.
09-14.name: National Cream-Filled Donut Day

09-14.description: National Eat a Hoagie Day, observed annually on September 14th, is a culinary holiday dedicated to celebrating the iconic submarine sandwich known as the hoagie. Originating in the Philadelphia area, a hoagie typically consists of a long roll split lengthwise and filled with various meats, cheeses, vegetables, and condiments. The day encourages enthusiasts and casual eaters alike to enjoy this classic deli staple, whether it's a traditional Italian hoagie, a cheesesteak hoagie, or a customized creation.
funFacts: The term "hoagie" is widely believed to have originated in the early 20th century in the Philadelphia area, possibly from workers at the Hog Island shipyard, who were called "hoggies" and ate large sandwiches.

While "hoagie" is primarily used in Pennsylvania and parts of New Jersey and Delaware, similar sandwiches are known by various regional names, including "sub" (submarine), "grinder," "hero," and "torpedo."
In 1992, the city of Philadelphia declared the hoagie its official sandwich.
09-14.name: National Eat a Hoagie Day

09-15.description: Make a Hat Day, observed annually on September 15th, is an informal holiday that encourages creativity and crafting by inviting individuals to design and construct their own headwear. This celebration promotes personal expression through DIY artistry, with participants often using various materials to create unique and imaginative hats, fostering a spirit of fun and hands-on creation.
funFacts: The phrase "hat trick" originated in cricket, referring to a bowler taking three wickets in three consecutive balls, for which they were traditionally given a new hat.
Hats have historically served diverse purposes, from protection against elements to signifying social status, occupation, or religious affiliation.
The fedora, a popular style of hat, was originally a women's fashion accessory before becoming widely adopted by men in the early 20th century.
09-15.name: Make a Hat Day

09-15.description: National Cr√®me de Menthe Day, observed annually on September 15th, celebrates the sweet, mint-flavored liqueur known for its refreshing taste and distinctive aroma. This versatile spirit, made from mint leaves, is a popular ingredient in cocktails, after-dinner drinks, and desserts. Whether enjoyed in its vibrant green form or as a clear 'white' variety, the day encourages appreciation for this classic cordial and its many uses in mixology and confectionery.
funFacts: Cr√®me de Menthe was first commercially produced in France in the 19th century.
It comes in two main varieties: a clear 'white' version and a bright green version, which gets its color from added food coloring.
A prominent ingredient in the classic Grasshopper cocktail, it also lends its flavor to popular desserts like mint chocolate chip ice cream.
09-15.name: National Cr√®me de Menthe Day

09-16.description: National Play-Doh Day, celebrated annually on September 16th, is a vibrant occasion dedicated to honoring the iconic modeling compound that has inspired creativity and imaginative play for generations. This day encourages people of all ages to rediscover the simple joy of sculpting, molding, and creating with Play-Doh, fostering artistic expression, fine motor skills, and nostalgic fun.
funFacts: Play-Doh was originally sold as a wallpaper cleaner in the 1930s before being rebranded as a toy in the mid-1950s.
The first Play-Doh color available to the public was off-white.
The distinct scent of Play-Doh was officially copyrighted by Hasbro in 2018.
09-16.name: National Play-Doh Day

09-16.description: National Guacamole Day, observed annually on September 16th, is a festive celebration dedicated to the creamy, vibrant green dip. Originating with the Aztecs in Mexico, this day encourages enthusiasts worldwide to enjoy the popular blend of mashed avocados, often seasoned with lime juice, salt, and other ingredients, as a snack or an accompaniment to various dishes.
funFacts: The word "guacamole" comes from the Aztec Nahuatl word "ahuacamolli," which translates to "avocado sauce."
Avocados, the primary ingredient, are botanically considered a single-seed berry, not a vegetable.
Americans consume over 100 million pounds of avocados during Super Bowl weekend alone, much of which is used for guacamole.
09-16.name: National Guacamole Day

09-17.description: National IT Professionals Day, observed annually on September 17, is dedicated to recognizing and appreciating the vital contributions of Information Technology (IT) professionals. These individuals, encompassing roles from system administrators and network engineers to software developers and cybersecurity experts, are the unsung heroes who ensure our digital world runs smoothly, secure our data, troubleshoot technical issues, and innovate the technologies that power businesses, governments, and personal lives every day.
funFacts: National IT Professionals Day was officially founded by SolarWinds, a leading IT management software company, with its first observance in 2015 to acknowledge the critical work of IT teams.

Employment in computer and information technology occupations is projected to grow much faster than the average for all occupations, with hundreds of thousands of new jobs expected over the next decade.
Many IT professionals are on-call 24/7, ready to troubleshoot critical system failures or mitigate cybersecurity threats at any hour to ensure continuous operation.
09-17.name: National IT Professionals Day

09-17.description: National Apple Dumpling Day, celebrated annually on September 17th, honors a beloved dessert featuring a cored apple (or apple slices) wrapped in pastry dough, baked until golden, and often served with a sweet syrup or sauce. This comforting dish is a quintessential fall treat, especially popular in American cuisine, and the day encourages enjoying this warm, spiced pastry, often accompanied by ice cream or whipped cream.
funFacts: Apple dumplings are believed to have originated in England, evolving from similar fruit-and-pastry preparations.
Early American recipes for apple dumplings often utilized cider, molasses, or brown sugar-based sauces.
A popular tradition, particularly in parts of the Midwestern U.S., involves serving apple dumplings with a slice or even a piece of cheddar cheese baked into the pastry.
09-17.name: National Apple Dumpling Day

09-18.description: National Cheeseburger Day is an annual celebration observed on September 18th, dedicated to one of America's most popular and iconic dishes: the cheeseburger. It's a day for culinary enthusiasts to enjoy various iterations of the classic combination of a savory patty topped with melted cheese, served on a bun with an array of condiments and toppings, often celebrated with special deals and promotions from restaurants nationwide.
funFacts: While its exact origin is debated, Lionel Sternberger is often credited with commercially serving one of the first cheeseburgers in the mid-1920s at The Rite Spot in Pasadena, California.
The earliest known trademark for the name 'cheeseburger' was granted in 1935 to Louis Ballast of the Humpty Dumpty Drive-In in Denver, Colorado.
American cheese is the most popular choice for cheeseburgers due to its excellent melting qualities and mild flavor.
09-18.name: National Cheeseburger Day

09-18.description: National Rice Krispie Treat Day, observed annually on September 18th, is a sweet celebration dedicated to the iconic no-bake dessert. This simple yet beloved confection is made from just three main ingredients: Rice Krispies cereal, melted marshmallows, and butter, creating a deliciously chewy and crispy treat enjoyed by generations for its ease of preparation and nostalgic appeal.
funFacts: The treats were invented in 1939 by Mildred Day and Malitta Jensen at the Kellogg Company's home economics department.
They were originally created as a fundraiser for the Camp Fire Girls.
In 2010, the world's largest Rice Krispie Treat, weighing 10,600 pounds, was made by the Michigan State University Kellogg Center.
09-18.name: National Rice Krispie Treat Day

09-19.description: International Talk Like a Pirate Day is an annual observance held on September 19th where people worldwide are encouraged to speak and act like pirates for the entire day. Conceived in 1995 by John Baur (Ol' Chumbucket) and Mark Summers (Cap'n Slappy), it started as an inside joke among friends and gained international recognition after they sent a letter about it to humor columnist Dave Barry in 2002. The day is celebrated by using pirate slang like "Arrr!" and "Ahoy, matey!", sometimes dressing in pirate attire, and engaging in lighthearted activities related to pirate culture, often for charitable causes or just for fun.
funFacts: The holiday was conceived in 1995 by John Baur ("Ol' Chumbucket") and Mark Summers ("Cap'n Slappy") in Albany, Oregon.
They chose September 19th as the date because it was the birthday of one of their ex-wives, making it a date they wouldn't forget.
The observance gained widespread international recognition after syndicated humor columnist Dave Barry wrote about it in his column in 2002.
09-19.name: International Talk Like a Pirate Day

09-19.description: Butterscotch Pudding Day, observed annually on September 19th, celebrates the delightful and creamy dessert known for its distinctive flavor of brown sugar and butter. This comforting treat, often enjoyed chilled, is a popular choice for home cooks and dessert lovers alike, offering a rich, sweet experience that can be savored on its own or as part of a more elaborate dessert.
funFacts: The core ingredients for butterscotch are typically brown sugar and butter, often with cream or milk added for the pudding.
The 'scotch' in butterscotch may derive from the word 'scotching,' meaning to cut or score into pieces, a common practice for hard candies.
Traditional butterscotch pudding recipes often use egg yolks to achieve a smooth, rich custard-like texture.
09-19.name: Butterscotch Pudding Day

09-20.description: National Pepperoni Pizza Day, observed annually on September 20th, is a delicious occasion dedicated to celebrating one of America's most beloved and iconic pizza toppings. This unofficial holiday encourages pizza enthusiasts across the nation to indulge in and appreciate the savory, slightly spicy, and universally appealing flavor of pepperoni, often found as the star ingredient on countless pizza pies, highlighting its enduring popularity in culinary culture.
funFacts: Pepperoni is consistently ranked as the most popular pizza topping in the United States.
The word "pepperoni" is an American adaptation, not a traditional Italian word for a type of salami, derived from the Italian word "peperoni" for bell peppers.
When baked, pepperoni slices often curl up at the edges into small 'cups,' a phenomenon enjoyed by many pizza lovers.
09-20.name: National Pepperoni Pizza Day

09-20.description: String Cheese Day, observed annually on September 20th, celebrates the beloved and versatile snack known for its distinctive peelable strings. Often made from low-moisture mozzarella, string cheese is a favorite for its mild flavor, convenient individual packaging, and fun, interactive eating experience, making it a staple in lunchboxes and a popular go-to for a quick, wholesome bite.
funFacts: String cheese gets its unique 'stringy' texture from the *pasta filata* (spun paste) method, where cheese curds are heated and stretched.
The proteins in string cheese align in parallel fibers during the stretching process, allowing them to pull apart easily into strings.
While various origins exist, modern string cheese was significantly popularized in the United States as a convenient, individually wrapped snack in the 1970s.
09-20.name: String Cheese Day

09-21.description: National Pecan Cookie Day, observed annually on September 21st, is a delightful occasion dedicated to celebrating the rich, buttery, and often chewy goodness of cookies featuring the beloved pecan nut. Whether enjoyed as a classic butter pecan cookie, a chocolate chip pecan variation, or a crisp shortbread, this day encourages bakers and dessert enthusiasts alike to whip up and savor these nutty treats.
funFacts: Pecans are the only major tree nut indigenous to North America.
Pecan trees can live and produce nuts for more than 300 years.
The word "pecan" is of Algonquin origin, meaning "a nut requiring a stone to crack."
09-21.name: National Pecan Cookie Day

09-21.description: Miniature Golf Day, observed annually on September 21st, celebrates the popular recreational activity known by many names, including Putt-Putt, crazy golf, or minigolf. This day encourages people of all ages to grab a putter and a colorful ball to navigate whimsical courses featuring obstacles like windmills, castles, and loop-de-loops, offering a fun and accessible way to enjoy a scaled-down version of golf.
funFacts: The first miniature golf course in the United States, named "Thistle Dhu," opened in Pinehurst, North Carolina, in 1916.
Early miniature golf courses sometimes used unusual materials for greens, such as crushed cottonseed hulls, sand, or sawdust.
"Putt-Putt" is a registered trademark, specifically referring to a particular design and franchise system of miniature golf courses.
09-21.name: Miniature Golf Day

09-22.description: Hobbit Day, celebrated annually on September 22nd, commemorates the shared birthdays of the beloved hobbit characters Bilbo Baggins and Frodo Baggins from J.R.R. Tolkien's iconic works, *The Hobbit* and *The Lord of the Rings*. It is a day for fans worldwide to honor Tolkien's literary legacy and the charming culture of the Shire, often observed with feasts, themed gatherings, and reflections on the stories.
funFacts: The specific date of September 22nd is explicitly mentioned as the shared birthday of Bilbo and Frodo Baggins in *The Lord of the Rings*.
Hobbit Day is the highlight of "Tolkien Week," an annual celebration organized by the American Tolkien Society since 1978.
Fans often celebrate by indulging in multiple meals, especially "second breakfast," walking barefoot, and enjoying nature, much like the hobbits themselves.
09-22.name: Hobbit Day

09-22.description: Ice Cream Cone Day, observed annually on September 22nd, is a delightful celebration of the crispy, edible container that revolutionized the way we enjoy ice cream. This holiday honors the simple yet ingenious invention that allows us to savor our favorite frozen treat on the go, making it a beloved symbol of sweet indulgence and summertime joy.
funFacts: The widespread popularity of the ice cream cone is often attributed to the 1904 St. Louis World's Fair, where an ice cream vendor reportedly ran out of dishes and teamed up with a waffle vendor.
Syrian immigrant Ernest Hamwi, a waffle maker at the 1904 World's Fair, is frequently cited as one of the first to roll his thin waffles into a cone shape to help an adjacent ice cream vendor.
Antonio Valvona of Manchester, England, patented an apparatus for baking biscuit cups for ice cream in 1902, predating the St. Louis fair events often cited for popularizing the cone.
09-22.name: Ice Cream Cone Day

09-23.description: Checkers Day, observed annually on September 23rd, is an unofficial holiday dedicated to celebrating the classic strategy board game of checkers. It encourages people of all ages to engage in a friendly game, appreciate the game's rich history, and enjoy the mental exercise it provides, often serving as a nostalgic reminder of simpler times and face-to-face interaction.
funFacts: Checkers, also known as draughts, is one of the oldest known board games, with archaeological evidence suggesting precursors date back to ancient Mesopotamia and Egypt.

In 2007, the computer program Chinook, developed by Jonathan Schaeffer, officially 'solved' the game of checkers, proving that with perfect play from both sides, the game will always result in a draw.
The most common variation in the United States and Canada is 'American Checkers' or 'English Draughts,' which is played on an 8x8 board with 12 pieces per player.
09-23.name: Checkers Day

09-23.description: National Great American Pot Pie Day, observed annually on September 23rd, celebrates the ultimate savory comfort food: the pot pie. This beloved dish typically features a rich, flavorful filling of meat (like chicken or beef), vegetables, and gravy, all encased in a flaky, golden-brown pastry crust. It's a versatile and hearty meal, cherished for its warmth and home-cooked appeal, especially as the autumn season begins.
funFacts: The concept of pot pies dates back to ancient times, with early versions found in Roman and Greek cuisine where meat and vegetables were baked inside pastry.
While often associated with chicken, pot pies can feature a wide variety of savory fillings, including beef, turkey, seafood, or vegetarian combinations, typically bound by a creamy sauce.
